assigned_cwe_name: Buffer Copy without Checking Size of Input ('Classic Buffer Overflow')
cwe_description: The product copies an input buffer to an output buffer without verifying that the size of the input buffer is less than the size of the output buffer, causing a buffer overflow.
explanation: The code uses strcpy to copy a directory entry name (dire->name) into a fixed-size buffer within a struct dir_ent (dir->dirs[dir->dir_count].name). The maximum length of dire->name is determined by SQUASHFS_NAME_LEN (up to SQUASHFS_NAME_LEN - 1 characters plus null terminator). If the size of the destination buffer dir->dirs[dir->dir_count].name is smaller than SQUASHFS_NAME_LEN, a buffer overflow will occur when processing a directory entry with a filename of maximum allowed length, leading to potential denial of service or arbitrary code execution.

assigned_cwe_name: Buffer Copy without Checking Size of Input ('Classic Buffer Overflow')
cwe_description: The software copies an input buffer to an output buffer without properly checking that the input buffer will not overflow the output buffer. This can lead to a buffer overflow, which can be exploited to overwrite adjacent memory, potentially leading to denial of service, arbitrary code execution, or information disclosure.
explanation: The code uses strcpy to copy the directory entry name (dire->name) into a member of a dynamically allocated structure (dir->dirs[dir->dir_count].name). While the source buffer dire->name is bounded by SQUASHFS_NAME_LEN (due to the dire->size check and the buffer allocation), there is no corresponding size check or length-limited copy function (like strncpy or strlcpy) used for the destination buffer. If the fixed-size buffer dir->dirs[dir->dir_count].name (which is part of struct dir_ent) is smaller than SQUASHFS_NAME_LEN + 1, a buffer overflow will occur when a long filename is encountered. This can lead to memory corruption, denial of service, or potentially arbitrary code execution.
